The proposed system aims to alleviate the cold-start problem by utilizing a knowledge base (ClimateKB) of climate change causes and effects, as well as their associations with personal values. Since a comprehensive ClimateKB does not exist, we revisit knowledge base construction techniques and build a ClimateKB from free text. The ClimateKB and associated code will be open-sourced to encourage future research and applications.

Introduction

Climate change is widely recognized as one of the most significant global challenges facing humanity (Masson-Delmotte et al., 2018). Despite 72% of adult Americans acknowledging global warming, there is a lack of acceptance that it affects them personally and a lack of motivation to address it (Howe et al., 2015; Leiserowitz & A., 2021). This is evident in the fact that 47% of Americans believe global warming will have little or no impact on them, and two-thirds rarely or never discuss climate change. The lack of public engagement on climate change can hinder a country's ability to meet its Nationally Determined Contribution to reduce emissions under the Paris agreement.

Another critical factor contributing to the lack of motivation and disconnect with personal risk acceptance is cognitive biases, such as confirmation bias, motivated reasoning, and cultural cognition. Standard climate change communication must not ignore these biases and will likely be ineffective if it assumes a passive, blank-slate audience (Scheufele, 2014; Druckman & McGrath, 2019; Akin & Landrum, 2017). Effective and motivating climate communication requires transmission to be shaped based on underlying values, mental, and cultural models of the audience, as well as practical, viable, accessible, and attractive solutions (Carpenter, 2019; Iyengar & Massey, 2019).

Our goal is to make climate communication more effective by developing a recommendation system informed by personal values and powered by climate change concepts mined from current, reputable, and truthful climate news articles. Inspired by framing theory (Chong & Druckman, 2007), the system aims to present each user with climate change impacts and solutions that are most relevant and motivational based on their personal values. To achieve this, the system must:

1. Access a knowledge base of climate change impacts and solutions
2. Obtain a user's motivational profile
3. Rank the climate concepts based on the user's profile

Figure 1 illustrates the proposed recommendation system.

Figure 1: Effective climate communications using ClimateKB and relevance characteristics from a user's profile.

The schema for solutions in the knowledge base relies on having impacts standardized. Therefore, we focus on curating impacts as cause-effect concepts before defining a climate solutions schema. Traditionally, domain experts would curate the knowledge base with these concepts from climate science articles. However, manual curation is difficult to scale, and automatic curation techniques fail to generalize well to new domains (Auer et al., 2007; Etzioni et al., 2008; Mintz et al., 2009).

In this work, we develop a novel knowledge discovery system to build a climate knowledge base (ClimateKB) semi-automatically from articles. Additionally, the climate concepts in ClimateKB are linked to motivational reference characteristics by domain experts, as it is challenging to mine these correlations without user interaction information. We obtain a user's motivational profile using a questionnaire and rank the concepts in ClimateKB based on the user's profile.

To the best of our knowledge, this is the first initiative to build a ClimateKB and a climate recommendation system, revisiting open research challenges in these problems. Our main contributions are:

1. A knowledge base, ClimateKB, containing causes and effects of climate change
2. A knowledge discovery system for populating ClimateKB semi-automatically from text
3. A recommendation system powered by ClimateKB

Since ClimateKB has many potential downstream applications, such as fact-checking and retrieval, we will freely release it.
